title: On Feature Combination for Music Classification
segmentation: Hi, my name is Joey from from Monash University, Australia and this is work done in conjunction with Gore Jing Lu commenting attention junk.
Talk of this presentation.
We're going to address the problem of feature combination for music classification based on audio signals.
We basically try to address several questions, whether feature combination can boost performance, how?
Can we combine different features?
And also, what's the best individual feature?

Different types of audio features have been using previous studies for music classification at low level timber features and temporal features have most been used, and timber captures the quality of the sound that has to do with the instrumentation of the music and temporal captures.

The long term variation of timber, overtime and mid level features are extracted on top of low level feature analysis and these capture more intrinsic elements of music like pitch, rhythm and harmony.
Kind of briefly go over there.
Different combination methods.
These are basic standard ones.
There are two types of combination methods, decision level Fusion.
Basically try to learn individual classifier for each type of feature and then refuse the score of individual classifier.
Try to produce the final decision voting different voting methods and also sexualization.
It can be regarded as a classifier on top of classifier strategy and for feature level combination we.
We actually focus all the base classifiers to be the support vector machine, so the feature level combination we have started.
Feature concatenation in the input space and feature concatenation in the embedded space.
That's the reproducing kernel Hilbert space for as well.
Basically it's like average individual kernels and also a.
Method called multiple kernel learning, which is well known in the machine learning community.
I'm going to skip to the results.
Here this is the results of individual features.
We can see that some feature perform well subject do not, but there is no single feature that performs consistently better than others.
So this actually implies that we may get something by doing feature combination and this result of different feature combination methods comparing to the best individual feature.
We can see whatever feature combination methods it will perform better than the baseline.
I think we can find more information from the paper itself, that's all, thank you.
